column2: Poverty: Share of population living on less than $1 a day (after tax)
column8: This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and benefits. Income has also been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.
column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices.

column2: Total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day (after tax)
column8: This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the incomes of all people in poverty up to $1 a day. This data is adjusted for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries. Income here is measured after taxes and benefits. Income has also been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.
column9: This data is expressed in international-$ at 2017 prices. The cost of closing the poverty gap does not take into account costs and inefficiencies from making the necessary transfers.

column8: This is the average shortfall expressed as a share of the poverty line, sometimes called the 'income gap ratio'. It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than $1 a day. column2: Poverty gap index at $1 a day (after tax)
column8: The poverty gap index is a poverty measure that reflects both the prevalence and the depth of poverty. It is calculated as the share of population in poverty multiplied by the average shortfall from the poverty line (expressed as a % of the poverty line). Income here is measured after taxes and benefits. Income has also been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.
column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices to account for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Relative poverty: Share of people below 40% of the median income (after tax)
column8: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 40% of the median income. Income here is measured after taxes and benefits. Income has also been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

column9: This data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices to account for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Share below $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Number below $10 a day (after tax)
column5:
Number of people living in households with income below $10 a day.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Total shortfall - $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Average shortfall - $10 a day (after tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $10 (averaged across the population in poverty).

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Income gap ratio - $10 a day (after tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $10 a day (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.
column9: YlOrRd
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Total shortfall - 40% of median (after tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

column2: Income gap ratio - 40% of median (after tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 50% of the median income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - 40% of median (after tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Share below $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Number below $10 a day (after tax)
column5:

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Total shortfall - $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Average shortfall - $10 a day (after tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $10 (averaged across the population in poverty).

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Income gap ratio - $20 a day (after tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $20 a day (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column9: YlOrRd
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - $1 a day (after tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Share below 60% of median (after tax)
column5:
% of population living in households with {welfare['welfare_type'][wel]} below {povlines_rel['percent'][pct]} of the median {welfare['welfare_type'][wel]}.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Total shortfall - 40% of median (after tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.
column9: YlOrBr
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - 40% of median (after tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘post-tax’ — measured after taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: Share below $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column2: Total shortfall - $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Income gap ratio - $20 a day (before tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $20 a day (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Poverty gap index - $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Total shortfall - 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

column2: Income gap ratio - 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 40% of the median income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

column2: Income gap ratio - 60% of median (before tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of of 60% of the median income (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.
column9: YlOrBr
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Income has been equivalized – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

column2: Share below $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
% of population living in households with income below $1 a day.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Number below $20 a day (before tax)
column5:
Number of people living in households with income below $20 a day.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Total shortfall - $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of $1 a day. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Average shortfall - $20 a day (before tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $20 (averaged across the population in poverty).

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Income gap ratio - $30 a day (before tax)
column5:
The average shortfall from a poverty line of $30 a day (averaged across the population in poverty) expressed as a share of the poverty line. This metric is sometimes called the "income gap ratio". It captures the depth of poverty of those living on less than the poverty line.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

column9: YlOrRd
column12: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2021). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Poverty gap index - $1 a day (before tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of $1 a day. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

The data is measured in international-$ at 2017 prices – this adjusts for inflation and for differences in the cost of living between countries.

After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Number below 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
Number of people living in households with income below 40% of the median income.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.

column2: Total shortfall - 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
The total shortfall from a poverty line of 40% of the median income. This is the amount of money that would be theoretically needed to lift the income of all people in poverty up to the poverty line. However this is not a measure of the actual cost of eliminating poverty, since it does not take into account the costs involved in making the necessary transfers nor any changes in behaviour they would bring about.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

column2: Poverty gap index - 40% of median (before tax)
column5:
The poverty gap index calculated at a poverty line of 40% of the median income. The poverty gap index is a measure that reflects both the depth and prevalence of poverty. It is defined as the mean shortfall of the total population from the poverty line counting the non-poor as having zero shortfall and expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. It is worth unpacking that definition a little. For those below the poverty line, the shortfall corresponds to the amount of money required in order to reach the poverty line. For those at or above the poverty line, the shortfall is counted as zero. The average shortfall is then calculated across the total population – both poor and non-poor – and then expressed as a share of the poverty line. Unlike the more commonly-used metric of the headcount ratio, the poverty gap index is thus sensitive not only to whether a person’s income falls below the poverty line or not, but also by how much – i.e. to the depth of poverty they experience.

Income is ‘pre-tax’ — measured before taxes have been paid and most government benefits have been received.

Household income is divided by the total number of household members.

NOTES ON HOW WE PROCESSED THIS INDICATOR

The Luxembourg Income Study data is created from standardized household survey microdata available in their LISSY platform. The estimations follow the methodology available in LIS, Key Figures and DART platform.

After tax income is obtained by using the disposable household income variable (dhi)

Before tax income is estimated by calculating the sum of income from labor and capital (variable hifactor), cash transfers and in-kind goods and services from privates (hiprivate) and private pensions (hi33). This is done only for surveys where tax and contributions are fully captured, collected or imputed.

Income data is converted from local currency into international-$ by dividing by the LIS PPP factor, available as an additional database in the system.

Incomes are top and bottom-coded by replacing negative values with zeros and setting boundaries for extreme values of log income: at the top Q3 plus 3 times the interquartile range (Q3-Q1), and at the bottom Q1 minus 3 times the interquartile range.

Incomes are equivalized by dividing each household observation by the square root of the number of household members (nhhmem). Per capita estimates are calculated by dividing incomes by the number of household members.

Poverty indicators are obtained by using Stata’s povdeco function. Weights are set as the product between the number of household members (nhhmem) and the normalized household weight (hwgt). The function generates FGT(0) and FGT(1), headcount ratio and poverty gap index. After extraction, further data processing steps are done to estimate other poverty indicators using these values, population and poverty lines for absolute and relative poverty.
